data.title: Sounding Out!
data.meta_description: 2 posts published by Wanda Alarcon and priscilla pe√±a ovalle during January 2011
data.text:
*The title of this piece is inspired by the short story, ‚ÄúMinnie Riperton Saved My Life,‚Äù by the poet & playwright, Luis Alfaro.

(Shuffle)

I watch you breathe,

I cannot sleep,

I touch your hair,

I kiss your skin,

And hope the morning sun won‚Äôt wake you too soon.

For when you wake,

and look at me,

You never know,

you just might see,

Another boy who crept in your room‚Ä¶

Take your time‚Ä¶(that‚Äôs what you told me),

Take your time‚Ä¶

But I fell head first, and I just don‚Äôt know what to do

‚Äî‚ÄúNothing Looks the Same in the Light,‚Äù Wham!

I was a teenager in the 80‚Äôs. I grew up in South East Los Angeles, Huntington Park, to be exact, H.P. for short‚Äîhome of the Huntington Park Senior High Spartans and the local after game hangout, Spartan Burgers. In those years, almost everyone in my school was Mexican and most kids were either preppy or cholos or Florentine Gardens disco-types‚Äîalmost no one was ‚Äúalternative.‚Äù That is, until we caught our first glimpse of Boy George on Video One with Richard Blade ‚Äì that MTV style video show that came before MTV. If you remember, or have YouTubed it recently, a key scene in the video for Culture Club‚Äôs ‚ÄúDo You Really Want to Hurt Me?‚Äù begins with Boy George stepping out of a swimming pool, fully clothed and dry (a lo-tech effect even by 80‚Äôs standards), wearing a flowing tunic, white-boy dreadlocks, and expertly applied makeup. I remember being instantly fascinated watching him dance to a reggae beat and hearing him sing so longingly about a mysterious ‚Äúyou.‚Äù I had never seen anyone who looked or sounded like that before, and I went from listening to my brothers‚Äô heavy metal records, my mom‚Äôs cumbias, and my grandpa‚Äôs Beethovens to listening to Culture Club, Eurythmics, Wham!, and Bow Wow Wow almost overnight.

Soon after, I started noticing in my neighborhood sprinklings of pink, purple and green hair, spikey egg white mohawks, brown boys in skirts and makeup, and the girls from St. Mathias High wearing black chunky combat boots with their proper, pleated, Catholic school uniforms‚Äìmy personal favorite look. And when I bought my very own first pair of 8-hole lace-up Doc Marten‚Äôs, I was forever transformed. I sensed that crossing fashion lines somehow meant crossing other lines too, although, I was perhaps I bit too young to really cross anything. As a questioning adolescent, I embraced the freedom that music, fashion, and expression represented. It‚Äôs strange to think about how such a global phenomenon took shape in my little eastside town. That time of 80‚Äôs new wave, the ‚ÄúSecond British Invasion,‚Äù told me something about who I would become. I learned fearlessness from the bold and transgressive acts of fashion and wit my favorite gender bending pop stars regularly deployed on American network TV. And I learned to ‚Äútune in‚Äù to the sexually ambiguous language of songs like ‚ÄúTime Clock of the Heart‚Äù or ‚ÄúNothing Looks the Same in the Light.‚Äù All of those blurred lines felt ‚Äúnormal‚Äù to me. And it meant later on that I didn‚Äôt have to have an identity crisis when I was coming out. And I really didn‚Äôt. I didn‚Äôt really think about ‚Äúidentity‚Äù in this way again until much later.

(Shuffle)

I‚Äôm only sad in a natural way

And I enjoy sometimes feeling this way

The gift you gave is desire

The match that started my fire

‚Äî‚ÄúThe Paris Match,‚Äù The Style Council

As I copy and sometimes re-purchase 25-year old lost albums for my new e-music library, I‚Äôve started to wonder about some of my musical choices. Why did I still like what I liked? How do I trace my musical habitus? Culture Club, George Michael, The Style Council ‚Äì they‚Äôre all on my iPod right now. And I ask myself, is my musical taste really so wrapped up in what I perceived to be my pop idols‚Äô alternative sexuality so long ago? In this post-gender, post-queer, post-race (rhetorically speaking), trans-border era, is there even such a thing as ‚Äúalternative‚Äù anymore?

Because when I listen to those old songs now, part of me still ‚Äúhears‚Äù the skillful crossing of gender lines in every ambiguously phrased lyric, like the Pet Shop Boys‚Äô clever line, ‚ÄúWhich do you choose, a hard of soft option?‚Äù And I recall vivid images of Annie Lennox at once crossing and keeping those lines in the video for ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs That Girl?‚Äù which ends with an impossibly queer kiss. (She queered the Lacanian mirror long before Black Swan!) I still sense how all of these wildly public expressions of queer desire, with all of its spectacle and taboo, flowed into my childhood home through the sturdy Zenith television set that brought us together to ‚Äúlisten‚Äù to music anew. And this kind of hearing has to do with a particular way of remembering my adolescence ‚Äì the memory of how felt for the first time to hear those songs and see the images of Boy George winking his long painted lashes at the video camera, seriously putting pressure on the word ‚ÄúBoy‚Äù; or seeing George Michael dancing with Andrew Ridgley in the macho ditty ‚ÄúWham Rap‚Äù, their two beautiful and stylish female band mates conspicuously superfluous in that dance. And also remembering how the combined effect put something like the question about boys on hold for me in a really powerful way. There were options out there, is what I understood, and that was all I needed to survive ‚Äì to save my queer soul.

(Shuffle)

Don‚Äôt make me feel any colder

Time is like a clock in my heart

Touch we touch, was the heat too much?

I felt I lost you from the start

In time it could have been so much more

The time is precious I know

In time it could have been so much more

The time has nothing to show because

Time won‚Äôt give me time

And time makes lovers feel like they‚Äôve got something real

But you and me we know they‚Äôve got nothing but time

‚Äì‚ÄúTime Clock of the Heart,‚Äù Culture Club

But I also detect another kind of crossing, or rather, multiple crossings in those same songs. Somewhere between the funk inspired bass line of ‚ÄúNothing Looks the Same in the Light‚Äù and the soulful oohs and ahs of Helen Terry‚Äôs backup vocals in ‚ÄúTime Clock of the Heart,‚Äù I sense this music also crossed a race and a class line, however precariously treaded. From the perspective of a young, working class Chicana, quickly interested in all things British and gay, it seemed to me that these young white British boys took up a mic and pen and left their own working class accents behind for the promise of America. Clearly raised on a diet of soul and R&B, their eventual collaborations with Luther Vandross, Stevie Wonder, and Mary J. Blige ‚Äì American musical royalty ‚Äì seemed only natural on the Grammy stage. And I wondered in my youthful, pop star fantasies, how did they feel when they learned they could sing like that? What did it mean to be queer and black at the same time? Musically speaking. What was the bigger transgression? Because the 80‚Äôs were deadly years for many of us, on both sides of the Atlantic, who were confronted with the authority of the lines drawn by Reagan, Thatcher, and AIDS. Maybe the transgression is to survive. And to remember.

Listening as an adult now to George Michael‚Äôs greatest hits collection Twenty Five, it is easy to see that there is no longer any doubt about his sexual orientation. In songs like ‚ÄúAn Easier Affair,‚Äù he celebrates that he‚Äôs ‚Äúdancing with the freaks now/I‚Äôm having so much fun/I do my dance with everyone.‚Äù So I wonder, when your pop idols sex lives stop being curiosities or taboo, what still fascinates? Even their notorious falls from grace, and their celebrated ‚Äúcome backs‚Äù didn‚Äôt really provoke the public imagination in the same way again. But I detect there are still clues in the music. In his brilliant cover of ‚ÄúFeeling Good,‚Äù George Michael pays humble homage to Nina Simone saying: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a new day, it‚Äôs a new dawn, it‚Äôs a new life, it‚Äôs a new low/Oh we all know it‚Äôs too much to expect a man, a white man, to do it like Nina‚Äù (my emphasis). That simple musical gesture, a crossing of many sorts, tells me something about what she means to him. And I think that it has ever been and ever will be music that will save our collective souls‚Ä¶ I was seventeen when I left HP for a much larger Los Angeles. In some ways I was too young to leave home and sometimes I thought that I didn‚Äôt survive some things that came my way. But I always had a song to guide me and show me something new‚Äìa different way. I know I‚Äôll never fully rebuild my archive on something like iTunes. But as I contemplate my growing digital library, I really do believe that new wave saved my life.

(Shuffle)

Dear Listeners,

This year, my first book‚ÄîDance and the Hollywood Latina: Race, Sex, and Stardom (Rutgers UP: 2011)‚Äîwas born. The writing process required nearly a decade of thought and development, a gestation period that reminded me how to listen as well as see.

As a sound recordist in film school, I became acutely aware of the hierarchization of the visual over the aural: it was a challenge to claim space for sound when the director wanted to yell ‚ÄúAction‚Äù as soon as camera was ready. Me (covered in grime, Nagra deck over one shoulder and boom pole in hand): ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the frame line? Is my mic‚Äîor the shadow of my boom pole‚Äîin the shot? And, maybe I can get a level-check before we shoot‚Äîso the audio levels are as pretty as your exposure? Maybe?‚Äù

Yet, most of those instincts and that tenacity dissipated during graduate school. As I honed the language of film and television analysis, I, too, began to privilege the visual over the aural. Over time‚Äîand with the help of colleagues like Jennifer Stoever-Ackerman‚ÄîDance and the Hollywood Latina reminded me how to listen.

And so, I present a moment from the book that reinforced the scholarly importance of watching with my ears. In the following excerpt, I analyze Rita Moreno‚Äôs aural Otherness in West Side Story. The scene, like many others of Moreno‚Äôs career, illustrates the tension between the ‚Äúlook‚Äù and the ‚Äúsound‚Äù of the Hollywood Latina. While my book is primarily organized around the ways that racialized sexuality is encoded in the dance of the Latina body in Hollywood film, the chapter ‚ÄúRita Moreno, the Critically Acclaimed ‚ÄòAll-Round Ethnic'‚Äù helps clarify how the Hollywood Latina has been read as both ‚Äúeasy on the eyes, but hard on the ears,‚Äù a phrase used to describe Moreno during her appearance on The Muppet Show in 1976.

The excerpt explores a pivotal scene in the film, where Anita (Moreno) confronts Maria (Natalie Wood), whom she discovers has just slept with Tony‚Äîthe murderer of Bernardo (George Chakiris), Anita‚Äôs boyfriend and Maria‚Äôs brother:

[T]he nondance musical number ‚ÄúA Boy Like That‚Äù illuminates how the Hollywood Latina has also been aurally imagined and reproduced. [The song] expresses Anita‚Äôs anger and sense of betrayal, and eventually builds into a powerful duet (‚ÄúI Have a Love‚Äù) between the women. As a backdrop, the setting and bodies of the scene are visually coded as Latino/a: the apartment matches the purples, blues, and reds associated with the Sharks in the film, while the two Latinas in the frame‚Äîone real and one diegetic‚Äîare colored Puerto Rican through the use of brown makeup. These stylized signifiers set the tone for Moreno‚Äôs aural representation in the scene. As the only Puerto Rican in the film cast, Rita Moreno gave a performance that became a touchstone of aural authenticity for non-Puerto Rican actors such as George Chakiris (Bernardo). In one interview, Chakiris notes that he and the Shark actors used Moreno as their sonic ‚Äúguide‚Äù (Gross 2001). [Interestingly, the West Side Story shooting script available in the Bob Wise Collection at the University of Southern California Cinematic Arts Library includes written dialect for the Jets but not the Sharks, suggesting that the sonic expectations of the Latino/a characters were self-evident].

Both Natalie Wood and Rita Moreno lip-synch to prerecorded tracks, but unlike Wood, Moreno performs her other songs herself; ‚ÄúA Boy Like That‚Äù is Moreno‚Äôs only song that does not feature her real singing voice. While the dubbed vocal performance compensates for Moreno‚Äôs higher vocal range, it undercuts the ferocity of her physical performance. As Moreno‚Äôs facial expressions and posturing exhibit an angry and forceful delivery, singer Betty Wand‚Äôs vocal interpretation of the lyrics overly amplifies the supposed sound of a Latina body in lieu of the emotional urgency of the song. Moreno‚Äôs assertive body language is thus mismatched with the generic quality of Wand‚Äôs artificial accent, a kind of aural brown-face that flattens the scene‚Äôs intensity.

In a 2001 interview, Moreno expressed her disapproval of the vocals in ‚ÄúA Boy Like That,‚Äù claiming that Wand‚Äôs lack of acting skills resulted in a restricted interpretation that did not match the physical intensity of the scene. She explains: ‚Äú[Wand] just couldn‚Äôt get it the way I wanted it‚Ä¶to sound. It should have almost been a growl‚Ä¶you know, barely sung. And she ended up sounding‚Ä¶almost like a clich√© Mexican‚Äù (Gross 2001). Despite Moreno‚Äôs coaching, Wand could only articulate the song‚Äôs Latina-ness, a sonic interpretation that solely relied on a stereotypical accent to tell its story. This racialized vocal performance is incompatible with the emotional depth Moreno produces onscreen because it was only‚Äîalways, and already‚Äîaurally Other. [This shift is most noticeable at the moment in ‚ÄúA Boy Like That‚Äù when Rita Moreno‚Äôs dialogue as Anita suddenly shifts to the lyrics of the song].

Rita Moreno‚Äôs career enabled me to hear the Hollywood Latina, an experience that enhanced my analysis of Dolores Del Rio, Carmen Miranda, Rita Hayworth (Rita Cansino), and Jennifer Lopez‚Äîthe other women I study in Dance and the Hollywood Latina. I am thankful for Moreno‚Äôs (creative/political/critical) voice and hope that she continues to help me listen anew.

And thank you, dear listeners, for your time and attention. I hope to hear from you soon.

Sincerely,

priscilla.

PS: Dance and the Hollywood Latina: Race, Sex, and Stardom
